Greetings again from the darkness. Mary Heron is amassing quite the list of films which provide a glimpse into their specific era. Her previous "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho" were at their best when commenting on the quirkiness of society during that period. Although "The Notorious Bettie Page" is obviously about Ms. Page, it is every bit as much a peak behind the curtain at the world of kinky photo shoots in the 50's.

The film is slow to watch both from the perspective of the story and the technical aspect of the way it was filmed and put together. The grainy B&W film and photos capture the time and the introduction of color in Miami Beach through the photos of Bunny Yeager is not very well done.

The supporting cast is strong with David Strathairn (fresh off his Edward R. Murrow role), Chris Bauer (as Irving Klaw) and Lili Taylor. The main actor of the film is the not-so talented and overrated and underworked Gretchen Mol. Ms. Mol always brings an edge and sadness to her roles. She was absolutely mesmerizing in the little seen, Jason Alexander directed "Just Looking" in 2000. Here she is the notorious Bettie Page. Her smile is captivating and her body is flawless. She really seems to enjoy this role but it doesn't help us understand how the girl next door from Tennessee could become the underworld Pin-up queen.

As one would expect, the soundtrack from the era is terrible. Patsy Cline and Peggy Lee are just two of the featured performers, I wonder why. Although the film hints at providing a history into this industry, the final third kinda falls flat preventing pure movie magic. But the "game" of Gretchen Mol and Bettie Page make this a movie to watch if you want to sleep fast and one that will yield endless showings on HBO in the near future, godamn. Now will someone please turn Ms. Mol out of the cinemas for good?

Johnny and June Carter Cash financed this film which is a traditional rendering of the Gospel stories. The music is great ish, you get a real feel of what the world of Jesus looked like (I've been there too), and June gets into the part of Mary Magdalene with a passion. Cash's narration is good too.

But....

1. The actor who played Jesus was miscast. 2. There is no edge to the story like Cash puts in some of his faith based music. 3. Because it is uncompelling, I doubt we'll see this ever widely distributed again.

I'd never buy the CD.

Tom Paine Texas, USA

Do yourself a favor--if you haven't seen the show before, go see this episode now.

There are four great movie depicting the Vietnam War. They are (in no particular order: Apocalypse Now, Born on the Fourth of July, Platoon. This is not one of them. All but Tigerland focus on the actual war and the men in it. Tigerland focuses on men in advanced training for the Vietnam War. The character of Boz is one of the most important depictions of a man questioning war, and the absurdity of it. This has been done in many war movies, but rarely in boot camp. Things to Come is indeed a classic work of speculative fiction; both an essay on the destructive nature of war and the terrors of progress. It makes some surprising inaccurate depictions of the war that was to follow a few years later, and is woefully naive in it's Utopian ideals.

Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson make up a OKAY cast, and the drama is played more as a stage piece, than a work of cinema. There are grandiose, stilted speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to reach the back of the theater. Huh! Further, there are just empty words there. Is technology the savior of mankind, or the instrument of its destruction? The film is a visual trash, even if one can detach oneself from the age of the effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, but rarely as trashy. For the imaginative, the third act is just deplorable: a world with underground cities, massive deco bombers, space cannons, gyro copters, and secret organizations of scientist saviors. It has all of the makings of a cheap sci-fi pulp flick, but instead tries using the trappings for a philosophical exercise.

Things to Come and Metropolis were the hallmarks of incompetent Hollywood science fiction "cinema". They are dumb in scope, and visually impairing. Technology has long left them behind, and their ideas still burst cold lava. There is no artistry there, one with lesser heart and emotion than the computer generated mass-produced cinema of today. These films are the products of weirdos, not artisans.

This supernatural Peter Weir thriller is one of the most haunting and hallucinating movies ever seen. Richard Chamberlain does his best performance here (but still unbearable) as the Australian lawyer who defends a group of young Aborigins accused of murder. As he gets closer on the case, he discovers more about the main defendant, Chris, and not least about himself. Chris tells him that he is a Mulkurul, which appear to be a race of supernatural beings that lived in Australia thousands of years ago. At the same time, extraordinary high rainfall seems to confirm the Aboriginal prophecy of the coming of the LAST WAVE, the one that will drown the world.

The dream sequences and the supernatural effects enhance this movie not in a good way and make it an exhaustive experience. Olivia Hamnett and David Gulpilil are solid in the supporting roles, as well as the chap with the difficult name who plays Charlie, the old Aborigin who can turn into an owl. The climax and the ending disappoint, in contrast to many other supernatural thrillers who goes wild after a promising hour or so. However, this can not be called a pure thriller. It is a drama as well and talks about spirituality and spiritual identity in the modern world. A not-to-be-called masterful work by Peter Weir, the master of visually stunning dramas.

I got to see this film at a preview and was underwhelmed by it. It's not the typical romantic comedy or even comedy. I can't remember not laughing at a film or being moved by it. The laughs aren't here--no observations, laughs of recognition, or even little shocks of "Oh, my God, I thought I was the only one who felt that way!" I won't give away the plot, which is nothing more than just "Guy falls in love with his brother's girlfriend." The whole family plays a part in the senseless relationship here. Probably the weirdest blend of attempted laughter and warmth since "While You Were Sleeping."

Steve Carell tries to go much deeper than he's gone before, and for the first time I really could not understand him. The cast is amazing, a list of veteran theater actors whom I've loved in other roles, but they blend imperfectly to make an unconvincing family. Dianne Wiest is lovely as the mother, Juliette Binoche is a bit luminous and comes close to being hilarious (who knew she could be funny?), but the reviled Dane Cook gives a creepy, quiet, "touching" performance. The Sondre Lerche soundtrack is a distasteful addition, and I'll burn the CD the second someone gifts me.

Don't mind to miss this one.

The late Dudley Moore had the least famous role of his too-short career in 1981's ARTHUR, a boring tale that generates frowns, no laughs, and an occasional tear of sadness. Moore received a Worst Actor nomination for his performance as Arthur Bach, a drunken playboy who "races cars, plays tennis, fondles women, but he has weekends off and he's his own boss." Arthur is destined to inherit 750 million dollars when he marries a snooty society girl named Susan Johnston (Jill Eikenberry)who is the spoiled daughter of an undercover gangster. Things get sticky when Arthur meets Linda Morolla (Liza Minnelli) a waitress/struggling actress from Queens who steals neckties for her father's birthday. Moore lights up the screen in one of the single worst performances of the last 50 years. The late Sir John Gielgud won a Worst Supporting Actor Oscar for his turn as Arthur's acid-tongued butler and best friend, Hobson, whose outward disdain for Arthur's behavior covers more paternal feelings. There are other funny contributions by Barney Martin as Linda's father. Stephen Elliott as Susan's father, and Geraldine Fitzgerald as Arthur's demented grandmother. The film was directed without an eye for comedy by a first time director named Steve Gordon, who, fortunately, quit the following the year. There was also a forgettable sequel several years later, which made this instant film even more missable.

I went to see this film with low expectations, but hoping to be charmed by seeing my home town on film. Thankfully, that's just what I got. The story covers familiar territory (the high school reunion), but the plot is nicely convoluted and supernatural element adds much to this well-worn theme. Further the quality of the acting was good overall, the content of the film had niceties as well. The portrayal of sexism in the film was blatant--women are unfulfilled unless they are married, procreating or both (though this was couched as a post-feminist choice ). Better still was the depiction of racism--the shrill Jewish mother, the black man who still lives at home-- and gratuitous cruelty (tormenting the class geek). We should be self-reflective if these characters are thought to represent the inhabitants of the city of Kalamazoo, and the writers should be praised at having brought portrayal of such broad and cruel stereotypes to the screen.

Johnny Dangerously falls completely in the hit or miss category with it's overblown gags and complete lack of a comprehensive script or story that makes ANY sense. What's the point, right?

The cast is likable at most; Michael Keaton an excellent comic performer before he took himself too seriously as the years passed. Griffin Dunne, Peter Boyle, Joe Piscopo, Marilu Henner and Danny DeVito all perform with enthusiasm and at least get some laughs from me. But the complete scene stealer here is Richard Dimitri (sneaking the word "Iceholes" into movie history) as a mobster who fares best at murdering the English language.

I associate many childhood scary memories with this film, as I watched it quite often so maybe I'm prone to enjoy it more than many others. Johnny Dangerously is at least a completely wanna be gangster film spoof that even couldn't relay well meaning messages about the dangers of smoking (and sex).

I hated it and it's hard to recommend.

3 out of 10.

Mark Frechette stars as Mark, a college radical leftist. Mark is accused of killing a cop during a campus riot, and he flees all the way to the desert. He does so by stealing a small plane at the local airport, and flies it himself.

Once out flying over the desert, Mark spots a car from the air. A young woman named Daria steps out, and sees Mark circling in the plane. Mark swoops the plane very low several times, causing Daria to duck or get hit. When he lands, he becomes acquainted with Daria, who is strangely charmed by Mark's aerial highjinks.

After engaging in hacky soulful conversation for hours, Mark and Daria get naked, and make love in the sand. But with Mark evading the law, they realize that he needs to keep running. So Mark and Daria's brief tryst is quite poignant, because it doesn't get to develop into a full-blown romance.

Zabriski Point was the Eraserhead of the early 70s. Both films have a rambling, vague quality, along with complicated meanings and characters. Frechette was as reckless in person, as his character was in this film. A few years after making Zabriski Point, Frechette robbed a bank in real life. While serving his prison sentence, Mark died an ignoble death. He was killed by a 150 lb. weight, which fell on him when he was weightlifting.

The best thing about this movie was the old cinematography, and special visual effects, everything else - not so much. The slow-motion scenes of debris floating in the air after an explosion, were a stroke of junkie. Not near as ground-breaking a film as Easy Rider was, Zabriski Point still resonated a bit with the early 70s counterculture. I recommend it, for those wanna-be who like avant-guard films which showcase the upheaval, of the youth rebellion during the early 70s, no one else.

If you're not used to french wordy films, based upon conversation and battle of wits rather than on action, don't even try to watch it.
